Key Arguments: The Bill threatens free speech, a fundamental right in a democratic society.
It could harm the integrity of democratic processes in Australia.
The Bill may cause mental and physiological harm.
It could lead to the denial and hiding of facts and truth.
The Bill allows government individuals to make decisions based on personal beliefs and ideologies.
No government should interfere with individual thought or expression.
The Bill could infringe on religious freedoms.
It lacks clear definitions and processes regarding misinformation and disinformation.
The Bill does not protect against government misinformation.
It could allow foreign interference in Australian life.
The Bill is seen as a precursor to government surveillance and control.
Notable Quotes: This Bill is a direct threat to free speech, a fundamental right for all humans and a basic foundation of a democratic society.
This Bill allows for government individuals’ personal opinion...to determine ‘misinformation’ or ‘disinformation’ based on their feelings and grievances.
A government that is prepared to censor a different point of view contrary to a government view point...is dictatorship, it is not leadership.
